description: This trap simply carries a single message. It can be used for
testing connectivity to an SNMP manager. By manually sending
this trap, SNMP trap configuration, networking and the manager
can be tested without triggering unwanted behavior.
This trap has no specific application, it can be used to embed a generic message.
objects.test: $SNMPTRAPCMD IXIA-COMM-TRAPS-MIB::ixiaGenericTrap IXIA-COMM-TRAPS-MIB::alertSequence u 9999 IXIA-COMM-TRAPS-MIB::eventIndex u 9999 IXIA-COMM-TRAPS-MIB::alertSeverity i 4 IXIA-COMM-TRAPS-MIB::alertType s EXAMPLE IXIA-COMM-TRAPS-MIB::alertDateTime s EXAMPLEE IXIA-COMM-TRAPS-MIB::alertMessage s EXAMPLE

description: A counting sequence number, used to identify the order of traps as well as detect gaps in a received trap sequence.
variables.name: IXIA-COMM-TRAPS-MIB::alertSequence

description: A counting sequence number, used to identify the unique event which spawned a trap.
variables.name: IXIA-COMM-TRAPS-MIB::eventIndex

description: The severity level of the alert from Recovery to Critical
variables.name: IXIA-COMM-TRAPS-MIB::alertSeverity

description: This is a unique number which identifies the type of alert. It is an alternative to using the OID as a unique trap type identifier.
See detailed decription for IXIAAlertType.
variables.name: IXIA-COMM-TRAPS-MIB::alertType

description: This is the system data and time when the alert-causing event occurred.
variables.name: IXIA-COMM-TRAPS-MIB::alertDateTime

description: This is an optional text message to provide additional details about the alert.
variables.name: IXIA-COMM-TRAPS-MIB::alertMessage

description: This trap is sent as a result of a file operation status change. Typically this
results from saving, loading or deleting files. Traps may be sent more than once
per operation, e.g. to signify the start and end of the action.
objects.test: $SNMPTRAPCMD IXIA-COMM-TRAPS-MIB::ixiaFileOperationStatusChangedTrap IXIA-COMM-TRAPS-MIB::alertSequence u 9999 IXIA-COMM-TRAPS-MIB::eventIndex u 9999 IXIA-COMM-TRAPS-MIB::alertSeverity i 0 IXIA-COMM-TRAPS-MIB::alertType s EXAMPLE IXIA-COMM-TRAPS-MIB::alertDateTime s EXAMPLEE IXIA-COMM-TRAPS-MIB::alertMessage s EXAMPLE IXIA-COMM-FILES-MIB::fileStatusLastFileOperSrcFileNameOrURI s EXAMPLE IXIA-COMM-FILES-MIB::fileStatusLastFileOperDestFileNameOrURI s EXAMPLE IXIA-COMM-FILES-MIB::fileStatusLastFileOperFileType i 0 IXIA-COMM-FILES-MIB::fileStatusLastFileOperCommand i 8 IXIA-COMM-FILES-MIB::fileStatusLastFileOperResult i 3 IXIA-COMM-FILES-MIB::fileStatusLastFileOperDateTime s EXAMPLE IXIA-COMM-FILES-MIB::fileStatusLastFileOperMessage s EXAMPLE

description: This trap is sent when the status of a user authentication changes. Reasons include:
- user is rejected during authentication (failed login)
- user is acepted during authentication (successful login)
- user ends session (logout)
userSessionsName is the username
userSessionsSessionId is the unique session number (because the same username may be logged in several times simultaneously). Invalid if user fails to log in.
userSessionsPrivlevel is 1, 2 or 3 for admin, user or viewer priv level. Invalid if user fails to log in.
userSessionsAuthMethod is either pam (uses local user database) or external (external AAA server). Will be empty for rejected user.
userSessionsClientType is either cli, web, or netconf. SNMP sessions are not tracked like other user sessions are.

The somewhat misleading-named userSessionsType indicates the external AAA server type (if applicable); both userSessionsType and userSessionsSrvIp objects will only be valid if userSessionAuthMethod = external
The aaaServerStatusCurrStatus applies regardless of whether authentication was done internally (PAM) or externally. This object indicates the outcome or event - reject, accept, logout
For reject case, the following objects will not be valid: userSessionsSessionId, userSessionsGroup, userSessionsPrivlevel
objects.test: $SNMPTRAPCMD IXIA-COMM-TRAPS-MIB::ixiaUserAuthenticationStatusChangedTrap IXIA-COMM-TRAPS-MIB::alertSequence u 9999 IXIA-COMM-TRAPS-MIB::eventIndex u 9999 IXIA-COMM-TRAPS-MIB::alertSeverity i 0 IXIA-COMM-TRAPS-MIB::alertType s EXAMPLE IXIA-COMM-TRAPS-MIB::alertDateTime s EXAMPLEE IXIA-COMM-TRAPS-MIB::alertMessage s EXAMPLE IXIA-COMM-USERS-MIB::userSessionsName s EXAMPLE IXIA-COMM-USERS-MIB::userSessionsSessionId i 9999 IXIA-COMM-USERS-MIB::userSessionsPrivlevel i 1 IXIA-COMM-USERS-MIB::userSessionsAuthMethod s EXAMPLE IXIA-COMM-USERS-MIB::userSessionsIpAddr s EXAM IXIA-COMM-USERS-MIB::userSessionsPort u 9999 IXIA-COMM-USERS-MIB::userSessionsClientType s EXAMPLE IXIA-COMM-USERS-MIB::userSessionsLoginTime s EXAMPLE IXIA-COMM-USERS-MIB::userSessionsProtocol i 0 IXIA-COMM-USERS-MIB::userSessionsType i 0 IXIA-COMM-USERS-MIB::userSessionsSrvip a 192.0.2.1 IXIA-COMM-AAA-SERVER-MIB::aaaServerStatusCurrStatus i 0

description: This trap is sent whenever the status of a SW image command changes. The
command may have been initiated by a user interface (CLI or webUI) or a remote
manager via SNMP or Net Conf. See IXIA-COMM-IMAGE-MIB for SNMP
objects which may be written to initiate commands.
objects.test: $SNMPTRAPCMD IXIA-COMM-TRAPS-MIB::ixiaSwImageCmdStatusChangedTrap IXIA-COMM-TRAPS-MIB::alertSequence u 9999 IXIA-COMM-TRAPS-MIB::eventIndex u 9999 IXIA-COMM-TRAPS-MIB::alertSeverity i 3 IXIA-COMM-TRAPS-MIB::alertType s EXAMPLE IXIA-COMM-TRAPS-MIB::alertDateTime s EXAMPLEE IXIA-COMM-TRAPS-MIB::alertMessage s EXAMPLE IXIA-COMM-IMAGE-MIB::imageImageCmdStatus i 11 IXIA-COMM-IMAGE-MIB::imageImageCmdPercentComplete u 50

description: This trap is sent whenever the system log is cleared. The loggingSyslogClearlog object
indicates which log or log files were cleared.
